segments.text: He could look at the weather map and say, it's going to stop raining at 1215.
We can go for a picnic.
We have to be back by 315, because the rain's going to start again.
And he was always right within 15 minutes.
So then, really just incredible.
Another man was a man named Sparrow Petterson, who later came to this country and became a professor of meteorology at MIT and president of the American Meteorological Society.
He was a good first-rate meteorologist, but not really with the great intuition that Bjerknes had.
Another man was an engineer named Odd Dahl, who'd been with Sverdrup on the Maud expedition.
The Maud was the thing which really shaped Sverdrup's life.
The Norwegians, ever since the 1890s, when Nansen
tried to do what he did and succeeded in freezing his ship, the Fram, in the polar ice.
He had the idea that you could drift across the North Pole.
You just got in the right place in the Arctic Ocean in a ship or something to live on.
And the other great Norwegian explorer, Amundsen, Roald Amundsen,
had a ship built called the Maud.
And they tried this stunt again in the 1920s, late 19, just about the end of World War II, going up to about 1923 or 1924.
The ship, they actually tried this twice, and altogether, it's fair to have spent seven years frozen in the Arctic.
profound experience.
There were only about five or six of them on the moor, a very, very small crew.
And being Norwegians, they managed to get along together for this ungodly long time in a terrible, what seems to me to be terrible, a terrible situation.
They did it by having, by being very rigorously disciplined.
Sverdrup went off one winter and spent the winter with the Chukchi.
Eskimo-like people who lived in Siberia, and wrote a book about it called Post-Chukchi Folket, with the Chukchi people.
Most of the time, he had a very full program of observations of all kinds of geophysical phenomena.
And he spent years and years writing up the results.
He was all over this by the time he came to Scripps, but he was then working on the results of the Carnegie, this non-magnetic job that I was telling you about.
And he really brought science, physical science, to the Scripps Institution.
Vaughan, his predecessor, was a
a paleontologist interested in corals.

And he was the, I guess, the leading authority on the taxonomy of fossil corals, and also on the taxonomy of the larger foraminifera, formed of these big things like the mumulites that you find in Egypt.
And the way he got into oceanography was by
deciding that in order to understand dead corals, he had to understand living corals, the ecology of living corals.

He made a famous series of experiments in which he took little pieces of coral and stuck them to something like a board or something like that, and hung them in the water, in tropical waters, and watched how fast they grew.
Heard that they grow surprisingly fast, about one centimeter a year or something like that.
And he always talked about the interrelations between marine organisms and their environment.
That's what he thought oceanography was.
One of the jobs that oceanographers had was to study those things.
That's something we now call ecology.
He wasn't very interested in
in physiology or biochemistry, didn't understand biochemistry.
And he didn't really think of marine organisms, as most biologists do, as simply instruments for studying biology.
He thought that oceanography should be concerned with, as I said, the ecology of marine organisms.
In this respect, he was
very much like his predecessor, William E. Ritter, the first director of the Scripps Institution.
Ritter was a professor of zoology at Berkeley, and he founded something here in La Jolla called the Scripps Institution for Biological Research.
If you go down that grade by the Scripps Institution, it's still called the biological grade.
I often wondered why it was called that, but then I, of course, found much later that it was simply because that's where the biological was.
Ritter had exactly the same notion that Vaughan had, that you had to study whole organisms.
He wrote a famous book called The California Woodpecker and I, which argued his point of view.
At that time, biology was going in just the opposite direction.
It was going down from the whole organism to organs and to cells and to molecules.
That's been the history of biology, really, for the last 70 years or so, 60 years, since about 1915.
And this, of course, has led to a revolution in biology.
But we're just now coming back to Ritter's idea that one of the important things that we need to learn about is a very much more difficult subject than the study of organs, or cells, or molecules,
is the study of the whole creature, the whole animal, or the whole plant in relation to other plants and other animals, which is a major part of their environment.
Ecology is a very important subject, which is worked on by a completely inadequate group of people.
There's not enough competent people in that field.

And it was because of Ritter's disgust, really, or vigorous opposition to the reductionists that the Scripps Institution changed its name in 1924 from Scripps Institution for Biological Research to the Scripps Institution of Oceanography.
Well, it became part of it.
He started it by...
every summer for about seven or eight years, establishing a biological, a biologist's summer camp somewhere along the California coast.
In those days, every university and every college tried to have a marine biological camp or station, because there's such a wonderful variety and diversity of marine organisms.
And he had a summer camp in various places.
He ended up in Coronado.
and interested a man named Fred Baker here in San Diego in his work.
And Baker persuaded him to stay and to settle here and have a permanent station, or at least come here year after year in the summertime.
And the last one they had, the last one of these summer stations they had was at the Cove, just north of the Valencia Hotel.
here in La Jolla.
And then Ritter became a very good friend of E.W.
Scripps, the newspaper man.
Scripps was a monologist.
He talked all the time.
And Ritter was one of the very few people who could talk back to him.
And Scripps was fascinated by this.
And he said, I'm not endowing an institution.
I want to endow a man named Ed Ritter.
Yes, I gave him that.
Scripps managed to con the city of San Diego into giving or to selling him a Pueblo lot.
He said, San Diego's an old Spanish Pueblo.
It has a great deal of land, which we call the Pueblo lands of the city of San Diego.
And they divided this up into lots of about 180 acres.
La Jolla is on several, two or three of these lots.
And there was 180 acres where the Scripps Institution is now, which Scripps was able to buy from the city for $1,000.
And the city wanted, this was a philanthropic, it wasn't a,
It was worth more than $1,000 even then, of course.
But they got it very cheaply in order to establish this, to build a permanent building there for the Scripps Institution.
And the first building there was the so-called Scripps Building, which is still there, built in the early 1900s.
And in 1912, the institution became part of the University of California as the Scripps Institution for Biological Research.
And Scripps and his sister, Ellen Browning Scripps, all together gave them an endowment worth about $500,000 in those days of stock.
Most of the stock was in the Detroit News, the evening news association.
And they still have that stock.
And that used to provide the salary of the director.
But of course, it's a very small part of the total income, minuscule part of the total budget now.
So the Scripps Institution, when it became the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, the name was changed basically because of Ritter's feeling that the biologists were going just the wrong direction.
And it became then the first
oceanographic institution in this country, one of the first in the world.
Not the first in the world, but one of the early ones.
Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, which is the next major institution in this country, was started about 1931, about seven years later after the Scripps became the oceanographic institution.
Although Woods Hole had had
course for many years something called Marine Biological Laboratory, which was a summer place for biologists.
That's still an independent entity at Woods Hole.
And they had also had the Bureau of Fisheries, Fisheries Laboratory at Woods Hole.
So they have a very long tradition of studying the ocean.
We had a man here named Francis B. Sumner, who was brought here by Ritter
Because he had done some very interesting early work on the color adaptations of fish to their environment.
Fish that change color when they're, like the halibut and other flatfish, that change color when they, or change their patterns and their scales when they, for different environments.
And Sumner became very much interested in the Lamarckian idea of proving or disproving the Lamarckian idea that acquired characteristics are inherited.
He tested this out with mice.
And he had thousands of mice.
And there was a mouse house up on top of the hill just overlooking the present campus.
And when Vaughan came, he made him
Sumner always described that the institution went wet.
And Blond thought that this work on mice was not really appropriate for an oceanographic institution.
So he made Sumner really stop it after a few years.
And Sumner went back to his fish and did some, continued to do very interesting things on adaptations of fish to temperature and to other environmental factors.
really just the kind of ecology that one thought ought to be done.
He's always quite bitter about having to give up his experiments on mice.
He was a contemporary of Morgan, a great Drosophila man.
And Morgan won the Nobel Prize, basically because he chose the right experimental animal, Drosophila, which reproduce every few years.
days or every few weeks, I guess it is, whereas mice take months.
So Morgan could get a great many more generations with an experiment than Sumner could.
It's an interesting example of how much of a role luck plays, or perhaps insight or intuition.
Sumner became a member of the National Academy of Sciences,
long after Morgan had won his Nobel Prize.
Well, I'm sorry I digressed to the early part of the institution.
But coming back to what I did, or what we did after I became an instructor and after I came back from Norway, a man named Francis Shepard appeared here in 1937.
I guess he'd actually been here before that.
He'd been here even while I was a graduate student.
He was very much interested in submarine canyons.
And he got a grant from the Geological Society of America for $12,000, I think it was, to study the marine geology off the Southern California coast.
By that time, we had a new ship.
The old scripts, the one I told you about, had blown up in the harbor here in San Diego, as it seems to happen to oceanographic ships.
They had an explosion which killed the cook, this fellow Frank I was telling you about, and very seriously injured, murdered Ross.
Never really recovered.
This was while we were in, Ellen and I were in Norway.
And so Harold Sparger managed to persuade
Robert P. Scripps, the son of E.W., was then the editor and publisher of the Scripps-Howard Papers, to buy him a yacht.
He bought Lewis Stone's yacht, called Serrano, S-E-R-R-A-N-O, and renamed it the E.W.
Scripps.
This was a famous early oceanographic boat in the United States.
It was a top-sail schooner, a Gloster schooner.
They cut off the top mast, but we retained the regular mast.
And for years, we sailed this ship as well as drove it under power.
Gradually, the mast got shorter, and the engines got bigger.
And after World War II, it gave up sailing altogether.
It was just really a powerboat.
This is in contrast to Woods Hole, which had a yawl named the Atlantis.
It was built about 1932.
And which Columbus Islin, the famous director of Woods Hole, was the first captain of.
She remained a sailing vessel all during her career.
But we gradually got it.
use the sails only to steady the ship.
You could try something to steady the ship.
By that time, we had a professional crew.
We had a captain and several members of the crew, in addition to the graduate students who still were also stood watches, regular sailors watches.
But the engine room and the officers, we had a couple of officers on the ship.
Other people like that were all professional sailors.
Shepard had brought out with him two graduate students, Bob Dietz and Kenneth Emery, one of whom is now a member of the National Academy.
The other is a famous
oceanographer and marine geologist with NOAA, the National Ocean and Atmospheric Administration.
He's one of the primary authors of the theory of sea floor spreading, Bob Dietz.
And he also brought with him two guys from UCLA, whose names I can't remember, who had an idea about building a coring machine.
device for taking cores.
I don't think of their names, but I can't think of the form of it.
They were basically engineers and very expensive taste.
They spent a lot of money on this damn coring machine.
The theory of it was that you would open a valve and the water would
rush into a chamber, and in the process...
I'm sorry, that's not quite right.
You plunged it.
This was a cylinder on top of a core barrel, and there was a valve between the core barrel and the cylinder.
You opened that valve, and the barrel would sink into the mud because of the suction created by this empty cylinder.
And essentially, mud would be sucked up to fill the back room.
The trouble with this device was that the forces were too great.
Something always broke.
We spent thousands of dollars on it.
It never really worked very well.
It was about that time that Kuhlenberg was developing his
really operated on a very similar principle.
And also when Charles Piggott was developing his gun, the Piggott gun.
And the Piggott gun, in fact, really worked pretty well.
Of course, the Hulenberg Corridor worked very well indeed.
That was much, the Kuhlenberg Corp really came after World War II.
And we, anyhow, what we, one of the major things we did was to study the submarine geology off this coast and the sediments and their distribution.
Then in 1938 or 39, I guess, 39, we had an expedition to the Gulf of California.
That was the longest.
farthest away from home the Scripps Institution vessel had ever been.

And we did all sorts of things, and we built what the Russians now call a, what do they call it, essentially a mixed oceanographic expedition, doing biology and geology and physical oceanography and chemical oceanography all at the same time.
Was that fairly unusual?
The early oceanographic institutions didn't do that?

Yes, they did, because that was the way that all these big expeditions had operated, the Meteor Expedition, the Challenger Expedition, and the, well, there were half a dozen others in the very early days.
The last big expedition, the Snellius Expedition in the East Indies, all of these big expeditions
conducted everything at once, basically because ships were so expensive.
The Carnegie did the same thing, chemistry and physics and biology and geology.
And that was what we did on our first expedition to the Gulf of California.
And this was a remarkable place.
In the first place, it was very wild.
Very few people there.
One island, Tiburon Island, still had Indians on it, living pretty much as they lived thousands of years ago.
Very, very primitive Indians.
There were a few settlements, the settlement of La Paz, the settlement at Loreto, half a dozen settlements altogether, small relics of the missions or
In one case, a famous mining camp, a copper mining camp.
But the most interesting thing about the Gulf was the water.
The water just, while the shore was a desert, the water just teemed with life.
And this was because of the very peculiar circulation.
It had been called by Cortes the Mare Vermejo, the Vermilion Sea.
The reason it was called the Vermilion Sea was that it looked like tomato soup in the springtime.

You had an enormous plankton bloom every spring, and literally if you went out in a small boat at night and dipped your oars in the water, the whole sea would light up for hundreds of yards around the ship from luminescent organisms.
And the reason for this was that the surface water of the gulf was blown out of the gulf
by northerly winds, and deep water came in to take its place.
And deep water was rich in nutrients.
Surface water was poorer with nutrients.
So the nutrient concentration was extremely high.
And it came right up to the surface where the plankton organisms live.
The bottom deposits, as a result,

literally almost nothing but diatoms diatoms and other skeletons of other plankton organisms and these were layered in bars layer after layer the bottom in other words was anaerobic there was so much organic matter settling to the bottom oxygen was all used up so you got beautiful layered sediments and the of course the
The chemistry of the water was fascinating, and the geology was even more fascinating, because we didn't know it then, but this is the border of the two tectonic plates.
And you get these very complicated trenches and ridges and troughs and other zones of extreme tectonic activity, because it was right in there.
because it was right on the edge of the Pacific plate and the North American plate.
It's a continuation of the South Pacific, the Easter Island rise, and the San Andreas Rift in California itself.
It's a place very much like the Rift Valley in Africa and the Red Sea, which is where the Earth is pulling apart.
We didn't, of course, know it then, but we were fascinated by it.
had a very complicated basin and range structure of the place, and these basins each had these anaerobic conditions in them.
And so we went back again.
We got a grant from the Geological Society of America, another grant, and went back again to the Gulf.
And at that time, it was a purely geological expedition.
Emory was on it, and Charlie Anderson, the Geological Survey,

Fran Shepard and I, and several of our younger people, quite a few publications came out of this on the geology of the, not only the marine, but the land geology of the lower California and the Gulf of California.
And the whole thing was really exploration of a very interesting kind.
At about that time, the war started in Europe in 1939.
It started the summer or the fall of the year that 1939, there was another meeting of the International Union of Geology and Geophysics in Washington.
It was a very sad meeting because the war had started.
All these people from Europe that I told you about before were there at that meeting, too.
Many of them we never saw again.
And we here at Scripps were getting interested in underwater sound.
There was a naval officer named Ross Bennett, R-A-W-S-O-N-E-N-N-E-T-T, two T's, who was the
operations officer or technical officer of a division of destroyers here which were testing sonar here.
The head of the skipper of this division was a man named Berhans, who later became an admiral.
They both became admirals.
And they were really testing, trying to understand what happened in the ocean to affect the performance of sonar here.
what we used to call underwater sound gear in those days.

And Ross and Bennett came out to Scripps and talked to Sparadrip and Dick Fleming and me, and we developed a theory of what was, of the propagation of sound in seawater, a ray theory, a very simple theory.
Essentially, ray optics.
At the same time that Ewing and Islam were doing it, it was all quite unknown to us.
And then later, the summer of 1941, I went into the Navy.
Can't change that thing again.
